ProfileStatus.description:
The user profile's current status.
- active = Profile is actively being used.
- archived = Profile is not yet deleted so it is still accessible by users when specifically requested.
- merged = Profile is no longer in use because it has been merged with another profile. Currently being used by Donor Merge Lite.
- gdpr = Profile is no longer in use because the end user deleted their own account.
- fraud = Profile is marked as fraud and should not be used in any capacity other than internal reasons.

If the profile status is updated to `archived`, `fraud` or `gdpr` the profile will be removed from any household it is associated with.

Rates.description: The specific fee values for different transaction types.

flat_fee.description: The flat fee in cents per payment applied to each card type payment.

percent_fee.description: The percentage fee applied to a payment for a ACH type payment.

flat_fee.description: The flat fee in cents per payment applied to each card type payment.

percent_fee.description: The percentage fee applied to a payment for a card type payment.

flat_fee.description: The flat fee in cents per payment applied to each credit card type payment.

percent_fee.description: The percentage fee applied to a payment for a credit card type payment.

flat_fee.description: The flat fee in cents per payment applied to each debit card type payment.

percent_fee.description: The percentage fee applied to a payment for a debit card type payment.

RecurringDonation.description: Representation of a recurring gift/donation to a given client and app, from a given donor with specifications for start date, frequency, interval etc.  This is a conceptual model representation of the give and recurring time_trigger currently in the wallet bc tables.

name.description: Campus name attached to donation if applicable, will not be included if the org has only one campus.

bc_id.description: Wallet legacy database id for backwards compatibility.

email.description: Email address of the given donor.

id.description: Primary fund the donation is linked to even if subfund.

name.description: Fund name for fund this donation is linked to.

id.description: Possible parent fund the donation for the above fund.

name.description: Fund name for parent fund if exists.

bc_id.description: Wallet legacy database id for backwards compatibility.

time_zone.description: Time zone for the given client in the IANA standard format, useful for making sure dates are shown in the client timezone instead of UTC.

expiration.description: The year and month that the card expires. Omitted for banks.

last_four.description: The last four of the payment source, encrypted before stored.

type.description: Type of payment source such as Visa or Bank.

profile.description: The donor who setup the recurring donation. See <https://openapi.docs.subsplash.net/end-user-auth/#tag/Profile>. Only returned when specified in the include query parameter.

id.description: The unique identifier for this profile.

properties.description: Terminal dba which is usually the same as the client name.

amount.description: Total amount for this RecurringDonation in decimal format, to two decimal places.

created_at.description: Date this recurring gift was created (ts_created in time_trigger record).

currency.description: The currency of the above amount (currently only "USD" and "CAD" are supported).

description.description: A human-readable description of the RRULE

donor_covered_fee.description: Flag indicating if the donor opted to cover fees.

donor_memo.description: optional donor memo they can add as a note to any donation or recurring donation.

id.description: The unique identifier for this recurring donation.

last_processed_at.description: References the most recent gift date related to this recurring donation.

next_process_at.description: The next date/time this RecurringDonation should process (basically becomes the "start date" of the specified recurrence rule).

org_key.description: The identifier for the owning organization.

recurrence_rule.description: RRULE specification string containing the parameters for the recurring donation rules such as "FREQ=MONTHLY;BYMONTHDAY=15;INTERVAL=1".

short_id.description: A shorter identifier for this recurring donation.

status.description:
Status indicates the current state of the `RecurringDonation`.

`active` recurring donations are recurring donations that will process at the time of the `next_processed_at` date.

`canceled` recurring donations are recurring donations that have been stopped by the end user or potentially an admin or employee.

`failed` recurring donations are recurring donations that encountered an error while processing the transaction. This error could have come from the payfac (i.e Stripe) or within another Subsplash service.

updated_at.description: Moment when the resource was most recently updated in UTC.

Refund.description: A refund is a reversal of a payment that was previously been created but not yet fully refunded. Funds are transferred back to the payment instrument that was originally charged. A refund is primarily performed on a payment via the giving dashboard from a client account.

issued-by.description: A generic pseudo-resource that represents the person that issued the refund (generally a person that's a part of the org owning the payment account). The resource includes a uuid and a free-form type field. Clients of the payment service can use this to relate the refund to the entity in that system that can issue a refund.

id.description: The id for the issuer resource.

amount.description: The amount of funds transferred for the payment in whole units of the smallest unit of measure for the specified currency.

created_at.description: Moment when the resource was created in UTC.

internal_notes.description: Free form notes concerning this refund that are only visible to clients.

local_created_at.description: Moment when the refund occurred in the timezone set for the Organization.

public_notes.description: Free form notes concerning this refund that are sent to the end user.

reason.description: The reason for the refund given by the customer.

updated_at.description: Moment when the resource was updated most recently.

RemoteDeposit.description: Remote deposit is a process where checks are scanned and processed through a payment facilitator's system before being linked to users and funds.

RemoteDepositItem.description: A RemoteDepositItem is a scanned check processed through a payment facilitator's system for linking to users and funds.

RepeatingEvent.description: Stores rules and definitions for the generation of repeated Event resources.

RepeatingEventUpdate.description: Stores rules and definitions for the generation of repeated Event resources.

href.description: A link to this collection or resource

SendAttempt.description:
An attempt to send a message to a Webhook's endpoint_url corresponding
to the occurrence of a subscribed event.

Session.description: A Session is a class/room/sub-event belonging to an event with the option for check-in.

SessionUpdate.description: A Session is a class/room/sub-event belonging to an event with the option for check-in.

SetupIntent.description: This is the response body when creating a Setup Intent

account.description: The payment account that's associated with this Setup Intent

profile.description:
The profile associated with this Setup Intent. Required for
guests. See
https://api-docs.subsplash.net/end-user-auth/#tag/Profile/operation/GetOneProfile

email.description: The email of the profile associated with this Setup Intent. Required for guests.

first_name.description: The first name of the profile associated with this Setup Intent. Required for guests.

last_name.description: The last name of the profile associated with this Setup Intent. Required for guests.

created_at.description: Moment when the resource was created in UTC.

verification_token.description: The captcha verification token for the Setup Intent. Required for guest users; omit for authenticated users.

Song.description:
A Song resource represents an audio file with metadata and images. Songs
may be associated with an Album.

Submission.description: The submission resource represents the successful filling out of a payment form's required information and processing of a payment, and record of the associated information entered by the end user.

fund.description:
The linked fund resource from the form.

Note that this can be changed during the lifetime of the form which is why it's recorded separately here. The Submission is responsible for recording the Fund at the time of creation rather than the API consumer. See <https://api-docs.subsplash.net/#tag/Fund>

instrument.description: The instrument used in the payment. See <https://api-docs.subsplash.net/payments/#tag/Instrument>

payment.description: The related payment for the submission. See <https://api-docs.subsplash.net/#tag/Payment>

payment-form.description: The payment form that the submission went through. See <https://api-docs.subsplash.net/#tag/PaymentForm>

responses.description: The related responses for the form's submission. See <https://api-docs.subsplash.net/#tag/Response>

created_at.description: Moment when the resource was created in UTC.

email.description: The email address of the user who submitted the submission.

first_name.description: The first name of the user who submitted the submission.

full_name.description: The full name of the user who submitted the submission.

last_name.description: The last name of the user who submitted the submission.

org_key.description: The identifier for the owning organization.

quantity.description: The selected quantity for the submission.

short_id.description: A randomly generated integer ID used to identify the submission. Also referred to as the Order ID. This value is an unsigned 64-bit integer.

tax_rate.description:
The integer value of the taxation rate for the payment in units of thousandths of a percent.

Note: If the tax_rate is passed during Submission creation, it is compared with what the backend will calculate to validate that the payment won't be charging a different amount from what the submitter is expecting.

unit_amount.description:
The integer amount charged per unit sold in whole units of the smallest unit of measure for the specified currency.

Note: If this amount is used during Submission creation, it is compared with what the backend will calculate to validate that the payment won't be charging a different amount from what the submitter is expecting.

currency.description: Three-letter ISO currency code, in lowercase. Must be a supported currency for the payfac and account.

value.description: The integer amount to be used for the payment per unit in whole units of the smallest unit of measure for the specified currency.

Terminal.description: A Terminal is a set of configurations and options used to handle payments from end-users. This resource does not include domain specific (i.e wallet/giving/donations) data. Clients of the payments service may choose to "extend" a Terminal resource in order to add additional information. The currency that the terminal accepts is the default currency of the account. The terminal is not responsible for the sending of receipts, but can provide information used in the receipts.

name.description: The name of the timezone. For ex. "America/New_York"

access_token.description: The access token a client can use to call Subsplash APIs

expires_in.description: The number of seconds before the returned acces_token expires

add_claims.description:
A JSON string containing a claims object to be included in the token.
This set of claims will be merged with the standard claims for the client.
This may only be specified if the API Client's can_define_scope is true.
Otherwise, an error will be returned.

add_headers.description:
A JSON string containing a header object to be included in the
token. This set of headers will be merged with the standard headers
for the token. This may only be specified if the API Client's
can_define_scope is true. Otherwise, an error will be returned.

claims.description:
A JSON string containing a claims object to be included in the token.
This may only be specified if the API Client's can_define_scope is true.
Otherwise, an error will be returned.

grant_type.description: The grant_type of the token request

TokenResponse.description: A TokenResponse is an entity used by end-user-auth to exchange token information.

success.description: Confirms if the token exchange was successful.

Topic.description: A Topic represents a group of users that is used with push notifications.

created_at.description: Moment when the topic was created

deactivated_at.description: Moment when the topic was deactivated

deleted_at.description: Moment when the topic was deleted

is_general.description: Indicates whether the topic is general (vs specific)

is_private.description: Indicates whether the topic private (vs public)

num_subscribers.description: The number of subscriptions on this topic

updated_at.description: Moment when the topic was updated

TopicSubscription.description:
TopicSubscription is a representation of a subscription between a user's PlatformEndpoint and a Topic.  In this case,
a user's PlatformEndpoint is supplied directly.

created_at.description: Moment when the topic subscription was created.

deleted_at.description: Moment when the topic subscription was deleted.

id.description: Unique identifier of topic subscription object.

updated_at.description: Moment when the topic subscription was updated.

Transfer.description: Represents a transfer (payout) that donations/payments may belong to.

created_at.description: Moment when the transfer was created in UTC.

id.description: The unique identifier for this transfer.

short_id.description: A more human friendly, short, unique, integer id for the Transfer.

UpdatedByUser.description:
Information about the type and UUID of the entity performing the update. Note that only a service can set this data directly on a request.
Otherwise, this data is derived from token claims.

type.description: The type for the entity performing the update. Allowed values are: `user.end-user-auth`, `user.accounts` or `service.{service_name}`.

uuid.description: The id for the entity performing the update. It can represent an Accounts User, an End User or a Service.

UpdatedByUserInput.description:
Information about the type and UUID of the entity performing the update. Note that only a service can set this data directly on a request.
Otherwise, this data is derived from token claims.

type.description: The type for the entity performing the update.

uuid.description: The id for the entity performing the update. It can represent an Accounts User, an End User or a Service.

Webhook.description:
A Webhook represents an endpoint that receives messages corresponding to
one or more Events.

created_at.description: Moment when the resource was created.

enabled.description:
Whether messages should be sent to the endpoint. To set this to `true`,
a valid `endpoint_url` and at least one event must be set.

events.description:
The events for which the endpoint should be sent messages. Each value
must correspond to the `name` of an [Event](#tag/Event).

org_key.description: ID of the organization to which the resource belongs.

secret.description:
Secret used to sign webhook.
TODO: link to docs for verifying messages.

updated_at.description: Moment when the resource was updated.

latest-membership-status-change.description: The latest membership status change resource connected to the profile.

BearerAuth.description: A valid token must be used with each request.

info.description: The Subsplash API provides programmatic access to the Subsplash Platform.
info.title: Subsplash API

get.description:
To retrieve list rows for a saved 'standard' or 'dynamic' list, filter[source_list] can be used.

To preview list rows for a dynamic list, filter[app_key] and filter[type] can be used along
with additional filters.

count.description: Number of resources on current page.

total.description: Total number of resources across all pages.

post.description: Creates a new ListRow for a 'standard' list only

count.description: Number of resources on current page.

total.description: Total number of resources across all pages.

post.description: Creates a new List

delete.description: Deletes a ListRow for a 'standard' list only

parameters.description: The ID of the resource to get
parameters.name: id

patch.description: Updates a ListRow for a 'standard' list only

parameters.description: The ID of the resource to get
parameters.name: id

patch.description:
Note that this API is a little different than most
in that it supports updates/creates for embedded list row resources.
It's important to note that the logic enforces list row positional
ordering such that if a new list row is inserted or moved, that it
may result in updates to other list row resources belonging to the
list, but not present in the patch request. It's recommended that
after a PATCH succeeds, the client refresh all list row items via the
List ListRow API in order to ensure no stale data is returned.

post.description: Creates the Topic Subscription (in the request body) by External User. An External User can resolve to multiple platform endpoints.

requestBody.description: Supply the Bulk Topic Subscription to create

get.description: Retrieves a list of campaigns based on the provided filters and pagination parameters.

parameters.description: eight character org code.
parameters.name: filter[org_key]

parameters.description: Filter by campaign title.
parameters.name: filter[title]

parameters.description: The ID of a desired campaign
parameters.name: filter[campaign.id]

parameters.description:
Earliest campaign start date to filter campaigns by where start_date is a valid RFC3339 date. Supports the `=` operator.
e.g. `?filter[start_date.min]=1996-12-19T16:39:57-08:00` will campaigns with start dates after this date.
parameters.name: filter[start_date.min]

parameters.description:
Latest campaign start date to filter campaigns by where start_date is a valid RFC3339 date. Supports the `=` operator.
e.g. `?filter[start_date.max]=1996-12-19T16:39:57-08:00` will campaigns with start dates before this date.
parameters.name: filter[start_date.max]

parameters.description:
Earliest campaign end date to filter campaigns by where end_date is a valid RFC3339 date. Supports the `=` operator.
e.g. `?filter[end_date.min]=1996-12-19T16:39:57-08:00` will campaigns with end dates after this date.
parameters.name: filter[end_date.min]

parameters.description:
Latest campaign end date to filter campaigns by where end_date is a valid RFC3339 date. Supports the `=` operator.
e.g. `?filter[end_date.max]=1996-12-19T16:39:57-08:00` will campaigns with end dates before this date.
parameters.name: filter[end_date.max]

parameters.description: the current state of a campaign. Can support multiple state filters i.e. filter[state]=active,done
parameters.name: filter[state]

parameters.description: Fields to sort on.
parameters.name: sort

parameters.description: The resources to include on the campaign.
parameters.name: include

parameters.description: The page number to retrieve.
parameters.name: page[number]

parameters.description: Maximum number of records to return.
parameters.name: page[size]

parameters.description: Determines whether the `total` field is included in the collection resource.

parameters.description: ID of the end-user to filter donations by.
parameters.name: filter[end-user.id]

parameters.description:
ID of the fund or subfund to filter donations by. Supports a single UUID or a collection of uuids.
`=` and `!=` operations are the only operators supported.
e.g. `?filter[fund.id]=!8bf8a196-730a-4087-af92-84a80af25618,ec16e842-4306-23f1-6b20-b606e51a2167` would
filter out donations that belong to the two above funds or subfunds.
parameters.name: filter[fund.id]

parameters.description: An alternative way to include donations marked "hidden". This is useful for getting the whole set of donations for an end-user without having to know batch ids. If you want hidden, and non-hidden, make a request that looks something like (?include[hidden]=true,false)
parameters.name: filter[hidden]

parameters.description: Status to filter donations by. Supports a single status or a collection of statuses using the `=` and `!=` operators.
parameters.name: filter[status]

parameters.description: Include or exclude refunded donations. Since a gift can be paid, and then refunded, including just a paid status filter may also include refunded gifts.
parameters.name: filter[refunded]

parameters.description:
Campus UUID to filter by. Supports a single UUID or a collection of uuids. `=` and `!=` operations are the only operators supported.
e.g. `?filter[campus.id]=:id1,:id2` will return Donations that belong to campuses of `:id1`, and `:id2`.
`?filter[campus.id]=!:id1,:id2` will return Donations that belong to every campus except those that belong to campus `:id1`, and `:id2`.
Also, an explicit value of `null` is supported for returning donations without a campus.
parameters.name: filter[campus.id]

parameters.description:
Amount to filter donations by. Supports a single int value in pennies. Supports `=`, `>`,`<`, and `!=` operators.
  e.g. `?filter[amount]=>100` will return Donations with amounts greater than or equal to $1.00
parameters.name: filter[amount]

parameters.description:
Minimum amount to filter donations by. Supports a single int value in pennies. Supports `=` operator.
  e.g. `?filter[amount.min]=100` will return Donations with amounts greater than or equal to $1.00
parameters.name: filter[amount.min]

parameters.description:
Maximum amount to filter donations by. Supports a single int value in pennies. Supports `=` operator.
  e.g. `?filter[amount.max]=200` will return Donations with amounts less than or equal to $2.00
parameters.name: filter[amount.max]

parameters.description: Filter donations by their associated recurring id
parameters.name: filter[recurring.id]

parameters.description:
Filter donations by their associated transfer ID. Supports a single UUID or a collection of UUIDs using the `=` and `!=` operators.
Also supports `=null` and `=!null` to filter donations that have or have not been paid out.
e.g. `?filter[transfer.id]=8bf8a196-730a-4087-af92-84a80af25618` will return donations with the specified transfer ID.
`?filter[transfer.id]=!8bf8a196-730a-4087-af92-84a80af25618` will return donations without the specified transfer ID.
`?filter[transfer.id]=null` will return donations that have not been paid out (no transfer ID).
`?filter[transfer.id]=!null` will return donations that have been paid out (have a transfer ID).
parameters.name: filter[transfer.id]

parameters.description:
Instrument type to filter donations by. Supports a single type, or a collection of types, using the following operators: `=`, `=!`.
e.g. `?filter[instrument.type]=Visa,MasterCard` will return Donations that have a `Visa` or `MasterCard`
`?filter[instrument.type]=!Visa,MasterCard` will return Donations that don't have `Visa` or `MasterCard` instrument types.
Note: if the special keyword `card` is passed in, it will expand into all of the card types automatically
parameters.name: filter[instrument.type]

parameters.description: Frequency to filter donations by. Supports the `=` operator with a single value.
parameters.name: filter[frequency]

requestBody.description:
Household to create.

Notes:
  1. A member can only be in one household at a time. If a member is already in a household, the request will fail.

delete.description:
This endpoint deletes a household resource and removes all of it's members, trusted people and guests from the household.

Notes:
  * A specific member can be removed by [PATCHing the household](https://api-docs.subsplash.net/people/#tag/Household/operation/UpdateHousehold) or by [PATCHing the profile](https://api-docs.subsplash.net/people/#tag/Profile/operation/UpdateProfile) and setting the household to `null`.
  * A specific trusted person or guest can be removed by [DELETING the household relationship](https://api-docs.subsplash.net/people/#tag/HouseholdRelationship/operation/DeleteHouseholdRelationship).

address.description: The optional address for the Household.

members.description:
The members of the household. Note that this will override any members set for the household. If not provided, or an empty array, the members will not be updated.

If the intent is to remove all members from the household, use [DeleteHousehold](/#operation/DeleteHousehold) instead.

Note: 1. Individual member profile changes are handled via the caller [PATCHing a profile](/#operation/UpdateProfile).

allOf.description: The role of the member in the household.

fluro_data.description: a hidden field used for additional fluro data included in this group

name.description: The first name of the household.

primary_email.description: The primary email address of the household.

post.description:
Adds a new Profile. Note that duplicate profiles per EndUser and Org are not allowed. Providing a profile with an end-user or address without an ID will create a new end-user or address if it does not already exist. The created resources will be returned in the response and in the pubsub created event.

Adding the Profile as a household member

1. If the profile is being added as a household member, the request body must include the `household_role` and the `_embedded.household.id` field. 2. If there are already 20 members in the household, the service will return an error.

Adding a Profile's grade/graduation year

1. Either of the fields `graduation_year` or `academic_grade` will be accepted when creating a profile. However, if both fields are provided, an error will be returned. 2. If an `academic_grade` object is provided, either `academic_grade.value` or `academic_grade.name` will be accepted. However, if both fields are provided, an error will be returned.

patch.description:
Updates a profile resource.

Updating Profile's status

1. If you would like to update just the profile status (without validating the profile), please use the [/profiles/{id}/status](/#operation/UpdateProfileStatus) endpoint. 2. Updating the status to `merged`, `gdpr` or `fraud` is not allowed through this endpoint nor through the [/profiles/{id}/status](/#operation/UpdateProfileStatus) endpoint. To update a profile status to "gdpr" or "fraud" please use the [/account-deletion-request](https://api-docs.subsplash.net/end-user-auth/#tag/AccountDeletionRequest) endpoint so all appropriate actions are taken per the agreement with Apple. To update a profile status to `merged` please use [merge service](https://api-docs.subsplash.net/merge/#tag/MergeJob/operation/CreateMergeJob). 3. If the profile status is updated to `archived`, the profile will be removed from any household it is associated with.

Updating a Profile's address

There are a 2 ways to update the address of the Profile. 1. Send a Address ID. If an `address.id` is provided, the service will attempt to look up and attach the requested address to the Profile.
Note: The service will throw an error if there is an issue linking the address to profile. 2. Send Address fields without an ID. If an addresses fields are populated without an ID, the service will create a new address and attach it to the Profile.
Note: If an ID is provided, the fields will be ignored.

Updating a Profile's houshold

This endpoint also can be used to add/remove this profile to/from a household with the following requests bodies.

Removing the profile from a household

``` { "_embedded": { "household": null } } ```

Adding the profile to a household

``` { "household_role": "parent" "_embedded": { "household":{ "id": "11111111-1111-1111-1111-111111111111" } } } ``` **Note**: When adding a profile to a household, the request body **must** set the `household_role` to a valid value according to the request body schema below.

Updating a Profile's grade/graduation year

1. Either of the fields `graduation_year` or `academic_grade` will be accepted when updating a profile. However, if both fields are provided, an error will be returned. 2. If an `academic_grade` object is provided, either `academic_grade.value` or `academic_grade.name` will be accepted. However, if both fields are provided, an error will be returned.

Since we have a use case for viewing canceled recurring-donations, we're adding support for a status filter in our GetOneRecurringDonation API.
Status to filter recurring donation by. Supports a single status or a collection of statuses using the `=` operator.
The `active` status represents RecurringDonations that have not been canceled or failed.
The `canceled` status represents Recurring Donations that have been updated to stop processing. Recurring donations with the `canceled` status are only returned when this filter value is included in the request.
The `failed` status represents Recurring Donations that encountered an error the last time it tried to process a donation.

post.description:
Rotates a webhook's secret. The secret may be rotated immediately
(when="now") or after a 24 hour delay (when="delayed").

Rotating a secret immediately will cause webhook requests to be signed
with the new secret, so webhook verification will fail until the local
secret has been updated.

Rotating a secret after a delay will not have any immediate effect.
Webhook requests will continue to be signed with the existing secret for
24 hours. After this time has elapsed they will be signed with the new
secret.

previous_secret_expires_at.description: The time at which the old secret will or did expire.

tags.description:
Welcome to the Subsplash API Integration Guide. This document is provided
for Subsplash clients who are interested in building an API integration
with Subsplash, in order to make your data more valuable and synchronized
across different systems. The content of this document is technical in
nature, so a basic understanding of programming and RESTful API
Integrations is required.

## Steps to Integration

At a high level, building an integration consists of the following steps:
1. Accept the Terms of Service for using Subsplash APIs.
1. Work with your Subsplash CSM to obtain access to the API docs and get an API key.
1. Read the docs to familiarize yourself with the APIs and how they work.
1. Start building the integration and testing it as you go. Reach out for
help if you need assistance.

## Use Cases
* Bidirectional synchronization of Donation data between your system and Subsplash Giving.
* Bidirectional synchronization of People data between your system and Subsplash People.
* New media content pipeline for publishing new video/audio to multiple platforms.

## Prerequisites

**Identify the systems**: Determine the different systems involved in the data synchronization process. Understand their capabilities, limitations, and the type of profile data they store. You can learn a significant amount about the Subsplash platforms system by starting with the Subsplash Developer API documentation accessible at [developer.subsplash.com](http://developer.subsplash.com) (work with your CSM to obtain access).

**Define data requirements:** Identify the specific profile data that needs to be synchronized between your systems. Determine the data fields, attributes, and any additional metadata that should be included.

**Determine the source of truth**: When synchronizing data between Subsplashs platform and your CRM or 3rd party system, youll need to determine the source of truth. This can vary considerably depending on the quality of the data in each system, the freshness of the data in each system as well as the user patterns of the different systems involved. Feel free to dive a bit deeper into this here: [Source of Truth](http://developer.subsplash.com/docs/getting_started/source_of_truth)

## Integration Methods

There are a couple options for integrating with Subsplashs platform.

**Direct API Integration:** If the CRM or 3rd party system provides APIs (Application Programming Interfaces), you can develop custom integration between their API and the Subsplash API. Use the APIs to extract, transform, and load the profile and donations data between the systems.

**Bulk Data Synchronization:** If the CRM or 3rd party system cannot directly communicate programmatically or it lacks suitable APIs, you can use bulk data synchronization. Extract the target data from your system, transform it into a suitable format, and then iterate through the data synchronizing the data via the Subsplash API.

## Synchronization Triggers

**Establish synchronization triggers:** Determine when the synchronization process should occur. It could be scheduled at regular intervals, triggered by specific events (e.g., user registration or profile update), or based on a combination of factors.

**Scheduled Process:**
_Cloud Solutions:_ [Amazon Web Services (AWS)](https://aws.amazon.com/) provides a reliable and scalable cloud service for running scheduled functions called [AWS Lambda](https://aws.amazon.com/lambda/) which can be scheduled in combination with [AWS CloudWatch Events](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonCloudWatch/latest/events/WhatIsCloudWatchEvents.html). Other cloud providers like [Microsoft Azure](https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us) and [Google Cloud Platform](https://cloud.google.com/) also offer similar services for running scheduled functions. In Azure, you can utilize [Azure Functions with Timer Triggers](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-functions/functions-bindings-timer), while Google Cloud provides [Cloud Scheduler](https://cloud.google.com/scheduler) with [Cloud Functions](https://cloud.google.com/functions?hl=en) or Cloud Run. These services offer similar functionality to schedule and trigger functions based on specific time intervals or cron expressions.

_CRM Solutions:_ CRM systems such as [Salesforce](https://www.salesforce.com/) often contain their own automation features. For Salesforce, using Apex, a class can be created that can implements the [Apex Scheduler](https://developer.salesforce.com/docs/atlas.en-us.apexcode.meta/apexcode/apex_scheduler.htm) which can be configured to run periodically. For an advanced ChMS such as [RockRMS, custom jobs](https://community.rockrms.com/Rock/BookContent/9#jobs) can be created which allow for all sorts of integration and customization.

**Event Webhooks:** Subsplashs webhook feature can be used to push data into your systems in near real-time when a resource is created, updated, or deleted. Note that using webhooks is a much faster, reliable, cost effective, and efficient way to synchronize data between two systems, and should be preferred over using a periodically scheduled full synchronization process.

## Data Flow

**Data transformation and mapping:** Most likely the CRM or 3rd party system will have different data structures or field naming conventions from Subsplash, so you'll need to map and transform the data during synchronization. Define the mapping rules and transformations required to align the data between the systems. You can access API documentation which includes definitions of different resources such as profiles, donations, or media items at [developer.subsplash.com](http://developer.subsplash.com). Note that some resources support storing an `external_id` field which is a free form string field that allows for you to reference a resource in any arbitrary external system by that system's unique identifier. This field is readable and writable and used to reference to some record in another 3P system they are using for importing or synchronizing data. This field is not validated, nor does any subsplash business logic depend on this field.

**Error handling and reconciliation:** You will want to implement mechanisms to handle errors and reconcile any data inconsistencies or conflicts that may arise during synchronization. Define strategies for data merging, conflict resolution, and error logging. Many CRMs or 3rd party systems have the ability to merge person profiles and also handle error logging.

**Monitor and validate:** Set up monitoring and validation processes to ensure the accuracy and integrity of the synchronized data. Implement logging, error tracking, and notifications to quickly identify and address any issues that may arise. Another reasonable strategy might be to simply notify a responsible individual via email if errors or abnormalities arise during the synchronization process.
tags.name: API Integration Guide

Requests are usually authenticated via a bearer token in the `Authorization`
header. The token itself is usually a [JSON Web Token (JWT)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JSON_Web_Token).

For example, a request might include the following header:
```
Authorization: Bearer eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9.eyJzdWIiOiIxMjM0NTY3ODkwIiwibmFtZSI6IkpvaG4gRG9lIiwiaWF0IjoxNTE2MjM5MDIyfQ.XbPfbIHMI6arZ3Y922BhjWgQzWXcXNrz0ogtVhfEd2o
```

Tokens can be acquired from the [Token endpoint in the Tokens Service](/tokens/#operation/CreateToken).

tags.description:
If something goes wrong when a request is made, one or more errors will be returned.

The error response is an object with an `errors` property, which is an
array of error objects. Most error responses will only contain one error
object. Attempts to create or update a resource may return multiple objects
containing validation errors.

## Error object
The error object may have the following fields:
* `code`: A string representing the type of error that occurred. See
  [Common codes](#section/Common-codes) for typical codes. This field is
  usually included.
* `detail`: A human-readable explanation specific to this occurrence of
  the problem. This field is probably always included.
* `source`: An object containing references to the source of the error,
  optionally including any of the following members. This field is probably
  only rarely included in Error objects.
  * `pointer`: A JSON Pointer ([RFC6901](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6901))
    to the associated entity in the request document (e.g. `"/"` for the
    object itself, or `"/foo"` for an attribute of that name in an object
    that looks like `{"foo": "bar"}`).
  * `parameter`: A string indicating which URI query parameter caused the error.

Error responses will also have a particular HTTP status code. In general,
the `code` property of the error object should be used instead.

## Common codes
These codes are returned by many or all Subsplash APIs.

| Code               | HTTP status | Description                                                                                       |
|--------------------|-------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| internal           | 500         | Internal server error. A specific detail message is not provided for this code.                   |
| not_found          | 404         | The requested path is not supported.                                                              |
| resource_not_found | 404         | The path is valid, but the resource with the given ID doesn't exist.                              |
| bad_request        | 400         | Generic bad request. Should usually be replaced with a more specific code.                        |
| missing_value      | 422 or 400  | A required field in request JSON was not specified. HTTP status is being migrated to 422.         |
| invalid_value      | 422 or 400  | A field does not meet validation requirements. HTTP status is being migrated to 422.              |
| duplicate_resource | 409         | Returned when attempting to create a resource, and one already exists that somehow duplicates it. |
| json_syntax        | 400         | The JSON syntax is invalid.                                                                       |
| json_content       | 422         | The JSON is syntactically valid, but not what the endpoint is expecting.                          |
| json               | 400         | Returned for JSON errors not related to syntax or content.                                        |
| authentication     | 401         | The given token is invalid, probably because of an invalid signature or claim.                    |
| no_auth_header     | 401         | The `Authorization` header was not provided, and is required.                                     |
| invalid_token      | 401         | The token is not valid. Reasons include invalid format, invalid signature, and expiration.        |
| authorization      | 403         | The given token does not contain claims that authorize the requested action.                      |
| too_many_requests  | 429         | The request rate limit was exceeded.                                                              |

## Error examples

### Invalid fields in request body
#### Request body
```json
{
  "org_key": "ABC123", // too short
  "address": {
    "street": "124 Conch St.",
    "city": "Bikini Bottom",
    "state": "Pacific Ocean",
    "country": "US"
  }
}
```
#### Response
```json
{
  "errors": [
    {
      "code": "invalid_value",
      "detail": "an org_key must be 8 characters",
      "source": {
        "pointer": "/org_key"
      }
    },
    {
      "code": "invalid_value",
      "detail": "Pacific Ocean is not a valid US state",
      "source": {
        "pointer": "/address/state"
      }
    }
  ]
}
```

### Invalid query param
#### Request
```
GET /payments/v1/forms?filter[org_key]=SPONGEBOB_SQ_PANTS
````
#### Response
```json
{
  "errors": [
    {
      "code": "invalid_value",
      "detail": "the org_key is not valid and a little weird IMO",
      "source": {
        "parameter": "filter[org_key]"
      }
    }
  ]
}
```
tags.name: Errors

tags.description:
Filters allow the consumer to fetch resources that satisfy a particular condition.
Generally, filters can be applied to the attributes of a resource, but that isn't
necessarily a rule. Filters currently only apply to [GetAll](#section/List)
requests. Only one filter may be given for each filterable field.

Only certain filters are allowed for each resource type. See the documentation
for a resource type to see a list of available filters. Requests that include
a disallowed filter will result in a `400 Bad Request` response containing an
error message that indicates which filter is disallowed.

**See also:** [JSON API recommendations on filtering](https://jsonapi.org/recommendations/#filtering)

## Format
Filters are provided as URL parameters in the following format:

![](/_assets/filter_railroad.png)

* `name`: The name of the filter, generally the field to filter on.
* `operator`: An optional [comparison operator](#operators).
* `value`: The value to filter against. Multiple values may be given in a comma-
separated list.

## Values
All values are provided as strings or comma-separated lists of strings. However,
filters usually expect a value that can be converted into the JSON type of that
field. So, an integer field expects a string containing only digits. A boolean
field expects either `true` or `false`. A date-time field expects an RFC3339-
formatted timestamp like `2017-05-23T15:35:57Z`. Certain filterable fields may
support a value of `null`.

### Lists
Multiple values may be provided for a filter by separating them with commas (`,`).
Any of the given values will satisfy the filter. If a comma literal is desired within
the filter value, it must be escaped (`\,`).

### Wildcards
Certain string fields may support wildcards (represented by `*`) in filter values.
These allow matching substrings. A `400 Bad Request` error will be returned if
wildcards are not supported for a field.

## Comparison operators
The default operator (nothing supplied) is `equals`. The other comparison
operators are:
* `!`: not
* `<`: less than
* `>`: greater than
* `<%3D`: less than or equal to
* `>%3D`: greater than or equal to

Certain operators may only apply to certain data types. Note that the 'or equal to'
operators must encode the `=` using url encoding to be able to differentiate it
from the query arg key/val separators. Also the 'or equal to' operators are only
supported on services running kit v3.57.0 or higher.

## Or Filters
Multiple names or values may be provided for an or filter by separating them with
vertical bars ('|').
These allows matching by either one of names/values or another.
Multiple names may be provided, fullfilling the condition to provide either one or
the same number of values to the filter. A `400 Bad Request` error will be returned if
number of values is not 1 or equal to the number of names in the filter.

## Filter examples
* `/resources`: unfiltered or default filtered
* `/resources?filter[foo]=bar`: return resources where the field `foo` equals `"bar"`
* `/resources?filter[foo]=bar*`: return resources where the field `foo` begins
  with the substring `"bar"`
* `/resources?filter[foo]=null`
* `/resources?filter[foo]=<5`
* `/resources?filter[foo]=bar,baz,qux`
* `/resources?filter[foo]=2017-05-23T15:35:57Z`
* `/resources?filter[foo|bar]=1`: return resources where the field `foo` equals 1 or
  where the field `bar` equals 1
* `resources?filter[foo|bar]=1|2`: return resources where the field `foo` equals 1 or
  where the field `bar` equals 2
* `resources?filter[foo|foo]=1|2`: return resources where the field `foo` equals either
  1 or 2
tags.name: Filters

tags.description:
Resource endpoints may support the `include` query parameter to indicate
which related resources should be included in the response.

For example, given a resource of type `Foo` with an ID of `12345`, the
resource may be accessed at `/v1/foos/12345`. If there is a resource of
type `Bar` that is linked to the `Foo` resource, the endpoint _may_ allow
requests to specify `include=bar` as a query parameter. The response to
this request will include the `Bar` resource in the `_embedded` object
under the key `bar`.

Multiple includes are separated with commas (`include=bar,baz,qux`), and
nested includes are specified with periods (`include=bar.baz.qux`).

If a resource type is specified in an `include` parameter and no such
resource exists, the response will be successful, but no related resource
will be present in the `_embedded` object. It is the client's responsibility
to verify that a resource was included before attempting to access its
properties.

**See also:** [JSON API on including related resources](https://jsonapi.org/format/#fetching-includes)
tags.name: Includes

The Subsplash API follows principles of RESTful API design. It is made up
of many [_resources_](/#section/Resources) that support several standard
[_actions_](/#tag/Standard-Actions).

Data is usually encoded in JSON. A few parts of the [HAL spec]
(http://stateless.co/hal_specification.html) are implemented, as well as
some from [JSON API](https://jsonapi.org/format).

position in the list, or is hidden.

The list rows of a 'standard' list may be manipulated using the standard actions, but list rows belonging
to a 'dynamic' list are not true resources, so they don't have an id attribute and can only be retrieved
in a collection that filters by a source list.

tags.description:
**Page-based** pagination is the mechanism used to limit the number of resources
in a response. This means that a collection of resources must be retrieved as a
page, and that a page number may be provided to get resources beyond the initial
page size.

**See also:** [JSON API on pagination](https://jsonapi.org/format/#fetching-pagination)

## Pagination options
There are two options available related to pagination: `size` and `number` (page
numbers start at 1). These options
are specified as URL parameters within `page[]` and each take an integer value.
Each resource type has a default page size, which will be used if one is not
specified. Each resource type *should* have a maximum page size. Requests that
specify a page size greater than this value will receive a `400 Bad Request` with
an [error](#tag/Errors) object that contains the maximum value.
Omitting the page number is equivalent to requesting the first page.

### Examples
* `/resources` returns the first page of N resources, where N is the default
  page size for the resource
* `/resources?page[size]=25` returns the first 25 resources
* `/resources?page[number]=3` returns the third page of N resources. As an
  offset, this can be seen as resource `((3-1)*N)+1` through `3*N`
* `/resources?page[number]=4&page[size]=10` returns the fourth page of 10
  resources, which is the 31st through the 40th resource

## Fields
Two useful fields that may appear in a resource collection are `count` and
`total`:
* `count` should be available for all resource types. Its value is the
number of resources in the current page.
* `total` is the total number of available resources across all pages,
based on the specified [filters](#tag/Filters). It may or may not be available
for a given resource type. Also, it may not be returned unless the
`Collection-Total` header is set to `include`. If it's available by default
it may be possible to disable with `Collection-Total: omit`. When not needed,
it should be omitted.

## Links
Each collection of resources in [HAL](#tag/Introduction) contains a `_links` object at the
root-level. Within this object are between three and five link objects.

The three that will always be present are:
* `self`: a link to the current page
* `first`: a link to the first page
* `last`: a link to the last page

When the total number of resources is less than the page size, `first` and
`last` will both point to page 1.

When the total number of resources is greater than the page size, the following
links may be available:
* `prev`: a link to the previous page (not available on the first page)
* `next`: a link to the next page (not available on the last page)
tags.name: Pagination

tags.description:
A SigningKey is a public and private key pair used to sign and validate
tokens.

Each SigningKey is valid for a certain period of time. There are always
two valid signing keys at any given time.

Each SigningKey has a field that indicate when tokens should no longer be
generated with the key, and one that indicates when tokens should no longer
validated with the key. These timestamps are separated by a sufficient
amount of time to replace tokens signed with the old key with tokens signed
with the new key.
tags.name: SigningKey

tags.description:
When requesting a collection of resources, sorting allows the consumer to specify
the order in which resources are returned. Each resource type may have certain
fields that can be sorted on, which probably (but not necessarily) correspond to
fields of the resource. If a request specifies sort fields that are not allowed
by the resource type, a `400 Bad Request` will be returned with a relevant
[error](#tag/Errors) object.

**See also:** [JSON API on sorting](https://jsonapi.org/format/#fetching-sorting)

## Sort options
Sorts may be specified with the `sort` URL parameter. The value of `sort` is a
comma-separated list of fields with directions.

There are two directions for sorting: ascending and descending. To specify a
direction, prepend the field name with `+` for ascending or `-` for descending.
Ascending is the default, so it's fine to omit `+`.

Omitting the `sort` option from a request may result in an unsorted response, or
the resource type may have a default field and direction that it sorts on. This
should be documented with the resource.

### Examples
* `/resources`: unsorted or default sorted
* `/resources?sort=created_at`: ascending `created_at` (oldest to newest)
* `/resources?sort=+created_at`: same as above
* `/resources?sort=-created_at,title`: descending `created_at` (newest to oldest),
  ascending `title` (a-z)
tags.name: Sorts

tags.description:
Some [GetOne](#section/Get-One) and [List](#section/List) endpoints may
allow clients to specify which fields should be returned in the response.

To do so, the client may specify a comma-separated list of fields in the
`fields[TYPE]` query parameter, where `TYPE` should be the singular, snake_case
name of the resource type.

**See also:** [JSON API on sparse fieldsets](https://jsonapi.org/format/#fetching-sparse-fieldsets)
tags.name: Sparse Fieldsets

Most resources support some or all of the following actions:
## Get One
Returns a single resource.

## List
Returns a collection of resources.

## Create
Creates a new resource.

## Update
Updates an existing resource.

## Delete
Deletes a resource.

tags.description:
The Tokens service is a centralized place to handle basic client access info
and the generation and signing of tokens for all clients including other
services, third-party clients, and developers.

Most actions to read and write data in this service can only be performed by
Token Admins. Auth tokens may be requested by anyone with valid API Client
credentials, and public signing keys may be accessed by anyone.
tags.name: Tokens Service

tags.description:
A webhook is a mechanism for sending real-time notifications or events
from one application to another. It allows applications or services to
communicate with each other by providing a way for one application to send
data or trigger actions in another application.

In a standard webhook setup, Subsplash will act as a sender, while your
custom CRM or 3rd party system acts as a receiver. Subsplash will initiate
an HTTPS request to a specific URL (known as the webhook endpoint)
provided by the receiver application. This HTTPS request typically
contains relevant data or information related to a specific event that
occurred within the Subsplash Platform.

When your custom CRM or 3rd party system receives the webhook request, it
processes the data and can take various actions based on the provided
information. This can include updating records, triggering workflows or
business processes, sending notifications, or performing any other desired
action.

# Steps to Receive Webhooks
You can start receiving event notifications by following these steps:

1. Identify the events you want to monitor and the event payloads to
parse.

2. Create a webhook endpoint as an HTTP endpoint (URL) on your integration
app.

3. Configure a new Webhook with the event type and endpoint. Save the
secret in your app's configuration.

4. Set up request validation to ensure you only trust real Subsplash
webhooks.

5. Handle events by parsing each event object and returning 200 response
status code.

6. Test that your webhook endpoint is working properly locally.

7. Deploy your webhook endpoint so it is a publicly internet accessible
HTTPS URL.

8. Update the config of your webhook to your production publicly
accessible HTTPS URL.

# Create a Webhook Endpoint
Creating a webhook endpoint is as simple as creating a new HTTP endpoint
on your integration app with a URL to receive events. You can use one
endpoint to handle several different event types at once, or set up
individual endpoints for specific events.

## Endpoint Requirements
* HTTPS & TLS
  * During testing you may use a HTTP (non-TLS) endpoint. When you
  transition your integration to production, our webhooks will fail to
  send unless your server provides a HTTP endpoint.
* Accept POST method
* Return 2XX response status code
  * If the webhook sender receives a response status code in the 400 or
  500 range, the sending will be marked as a failure, and the retry logic
  will kick in.
* Respond before timeout of 5 seconds
  * If your business logic takes longer than our stated timeout, please
  write your code to first persist the event information durably, respond
  to the webhook with a 200 status, and then process the event
  asynchronously.
* Redirects permitted
  * Redirects are allowed (HTTP response status code in the 300 range),
  but count toward the overall timeout of 5 seconds.

## Message Format
* Body
  * The body is a JSON object consisting of the following fields:
    * `id`: Unique identifier corresponding to this change
    * `event`: The event type. See below for the list of event types.
    * `before`: JSON object representing the state of the resource before the
      change. This field is only present for events that correspond to
      updates or deletions.
    * `after`: JSON object representing the state of the resource after the
      change. This field is only present for events that correspond to
      creations or updates.
  * Example:
    ```json
    {
      "id": "9ef4bb71-59e7-4c18-b3fc-133ceeae51cd",
      "event": "profile.update",
      "before": {
        "id": "167dc12b-8f05-4c77-a3f8-7eeafc09911d",
        "email": "test@example.com",
        "first_name": "John",
        "last_name": "Smith",
        "marital_status": "single",
        "created_at": "2023-09-21T18:44:36Z",
        "updated_at": "2023-09-21T18:44:36Z"
      },
      "after": {
        "id": "167dc12b-8f05-4c77-a3f8-7eeafc09911d",
        "email": "test@example.com",
        "first_name": "John",
        "last_name": "Smith",
        "marital_status": "married",
        "created_at": "2023-09-13T18:44:36Z",
        "updated_at": "2023-09-27T09:32:57Z"
      }
    }
    ```
* Headers
  * `Content-Type`: application/json
  * `Webhook-Timestamp`: The Unix timestamp (in seconds) when the request
    was sent.
  * `Webhook-Signature`: Cryptographic signature of message. See [Request
    Validation](http://localhost:6063/#tag/Webhook/Create-a-Webhook-Endpoint/Request-Validation) for more
    information.

## Event Types
| Event Type | API Docs | Description |
| ---------- | -------- | ----------- |
| donation.create | [Donation](#tag/Donation) | When a donation is created. |
| profile.create | [Profile](#tag/Profile) | When a profile is created. |
| profile.update | [Profile](#tag/Profile) | When a profile is updated. |
| profile.delete | [Profile](#tag/Profile) | When a profile is deleted. |
| end_user_login_event.create | [EndUserLoginEvent](#tag/EndUserLoginEvent) | When an end user logs in |
| response.create | [Forms](#tag/Response) | When a forms response is created. |

## Timeouts
The request timeout is 5 seconds. If that time elapses without a response,
the message is marked as failed with a timeout error. Consider returning a
successful response right away and processing the event in the background.

## Retry Logic
When sending messages to your endpoint, we'll make up to 10 attempts to
send a given message, with an increasing delay between each failed attempt.
After all retries have been exhausted, we'll mark that message as failed
and give up sending.

## Rate Limiting
After you set up a webhook to start receiving events, you'll want to think
through your requirements for how scale your endpoint to prevent webhooks
from overloading your systems. The shape of traffic from our webhooks to
your endpoint will directly correspond to the volume of changes that are
made to your data in our system. Specific types of events and times of day
can have significantly different throughput requirements, so be sure that
your system can handle those peak throughput times.

The HTTP 429 "Too Many Requests" response status code indicates the client
has sent too many requests in a given amount of time. A Retry-After header
might be included to this response indicating how long to wait before
making a new request. If you endpoint implements, we'll try to honor this
response if it falls within the allowed time for a single send attempt. If
not, then we'll fail that attempt and try again in 60 seconds.

## Request Validation
Webhooks are cryptographically signed so that the system receiving them
can verify they came from Subsplash. This is done by producing an
[HMAC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HMAC) and comparing it to the one
given in the `Webhook-Signature` header.

The HMAC's key is the Webhook's `secret`. Its message is the request body
concatenated with the value of the `Webhook-Timestamp` header. This value
is the Unix timestamp at which the webhook was sent. This value may be
checked to ensure the webhook was sent recently, to prevent replay
attacks.

### Request Validation Examples
The following code snippets demonstrate how to verify a webhook signature
and timestamp.

#### Go
```go
package main

import (
    "crypto/hmac"
    "crypto/sha256"
    "encoding/base64"
    "io"
    "net/http"
)

// validWebhook reports if the request's signature is valid and that the
// webhook was sent within the last minute.
func validWebhook(secret string, req *http.Request) (bool, error) {
    ts, err := strconv.ParseInt(timestamp, 10, 64)
    if err != nil {
        return false, err
    }

    // Verify that the webhook was sent within the last 5 minutes.
    if time.Now().Sub(time.Unix(ts, 0)).Abs() > 5 * time.Minute {
        return false, nil
    }

    // Read the request body.
    body, err := io.ReadAll(req.Body)
    if err != nil {
        return false, err
    }

    timestamp := req.Header.Get("Webhook-Timestamp")

    // Create an HMAC using the secret as the key, and the request body
    // concatenated with the timestamp as the message.
    h := hmac.New(sha256.New, []byte(secret))
    h.Write(body)
    h.Write([]byte(timestamp))
    mac := h.Sum(nil)

    // Decode the base64 signature.
    sig, err := base64.StdEncoding.DecodeString(req.Header.Get("Webhook-Signature"))
    if err != nil {
        return false, err
    }

    // Compare the HMACs without leaking timing information.
    return hmac.Equal(sig, mac), nil
}
```

### Secret rotation
If your webhook secret is compromised or you'd like to proactively rotate
it, you can do so by making a request to the [Rotate Webhook Secret](#tag/Webhook/operation/RotateWebhookSecret)
endpoint. This may be done immediately or after a 24 hour delay, to give
you time to update the secret in your system.
tags.name: Webhook
